An element of a set is an object belonging to a set.
The order of an element $a$ in a group $G$ is defined as the order of the cyclic group generated by $a$ in $G$. It is the smallest positive integer $m$ such that $a^{m}=1$.
Does the concept of a/an Element of a Set need to be defined for a definition of a/an Order of an element to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: To determine the order of an element $a$ in a group $G$, we must first establish that $a$ is an element of the group $G$. The concept of an 'Element of a Set' is fundamental in defining what it means for something to belong to a set, including a group, since a group is a special kind of set with additional structure (operations and axioms). Without the concept of an element of a set, we cannot meaningfully discuss whether $a$ belongs to $G$ or not, and consequently, we cannot define the order of $a$ in $G$. Thus, understanding and defining what it means for $a$ to be an element of $G$ (i.e., an element of a set) is essential before we can discuss the order of $a$.
